abstract: Carl Icahn may believe (and he may be right) that his corporate agitations have created $50 billion in shareholder value over the past few years, as Fortune reported last month. But the larger question — perhaps more important now than in years — remains: Do the actions of activist investors benefit the rest of a company’s stakeholders?
lead_paragraph: Carl Icahn may believe (and he may be right) that his corporate agitations have created $50 billion in shareholder value over the past few years, as Fortune reported last month. But the larger question — perhaps more important now than in years — remains: Do the actions of activist investors benefit the rest of a company’s stakeholders?

headline.main: Shareholder Activism: Boon, Bane or Both?
